I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2003 Country Programming Mission of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
the Government confirmed its request to ADB for technical assistance (TA) to prepare the 
Agriculture Science and Technology Project.1 The TA Fact-Finding Mission visited Viet Nam in 
June 2003 and held discussions with stakeholders, including officials of relevant government 
agencies,  external  funding  agencies,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  and  potential 
beneficiaries. The Mission reached an understanding with the Government on the objectives, 
scope, and implementation arrangements for the TA. The TA is included in ADB’s 2003 TA 
Program for Viet Nam. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The agriculture sector in Viet Nam has grown rapidly at an average rate of 4.2% per 
annum during 1990–2000. From a net importer of rice in the late 1980s, Viet Nam has become 
the second largest rice exporter in the world, and exports large quantities of commercial crops, 
including coffee, rubber, tea, pepper, groundnuts, and cashew nuts. This rapid growth was 
attributed  to  market-oriented  reforms  that  recognized  farm  households  as  the  key  unit  of 
production, liberalized land-use rights, and liberalized decision making on the purchase of inputs 
and sale of outputs. Science and technology (S&T) have played an important role in contributing 
to agricultural growth through improved agricultural inputs and technologies for farmers although 
the past efforts focused more on yield improvement rather than quality improvement. 
 
3.  As part of its 10-year master plan and strategy (2001–2010) and to sustain growth, 
employment, and exports in agriculture to help reduce rural poverty, the Government aims to (i) 
foster agricultural diversification into higher-value products and markets; (ii) increase factor 
productivity, value addition, and agro-processing; (iii) improve product quality for domestic and 
export  markets;  (iv)  facilitate  technology  development  and  dissemination  through  improved 
research and extension; and (v) increase rural industries, infrastructure, and services. 
 
4.  More effective use of S&T for technological changes is required to ensure food security 
and promote agricultural diversification, and to improve the quality of high-value crops and 
livestock  and  fishery  products  that  are  comparable  with  neighboring  countries  and  trade 
competitors. Access to new technologies by farmers and agro-based enterprises is essential 
when Viet Nam's agriculture is gradually shifting its focus from increased production volumes to 
increased production values by identifying new production processes and innovative products 
and marketing. These technologies need to be developed and disseminated in partnership with 
central  and  provincial  agencies  of  the  Government,  private  enterprises,  farmers,  and 
international  agricultural  research  institutions.  Major  policy  and  structural  weaknesses  in 
agricultural research, extension, education, and market information systems in the public sector 
are being addressed under the Agriculture Sector Development Program (ASDP).2 Reforms in 
these  institutions  will  also  require  investments  in  human  resources  and  infrastructure  for 
agriculture S&T that will enable them to contribute more significantly to agricultural growth in a 
changing global environment. 
 
5.  The agricultural research system in Viet Nam includes 31 research institutes and 12 
universities, and involves five ministries: the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development

(MARD), the Ministry of Education and Training (MOET), the Ministry of Industry (MOI), the 
Ministry of Fisheries (MOFI), and the Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST). MARD is the 
agency primarily responsible for agricultural research since the majority of research institutes 
and 2 of the 12 agricultural universities are under its supervision. Private universities and 
colleges are also involved in agricultural research. The regional distribution of public research 
institutes and their stations is rather uneven, with about 80% of them in the Red River and 
Mekong deltas. This situation makes it difficult for the institutes to address poverty reduction and 
environmental issues in remote and upland regions where research institutes and their stations 
do not exist. Under ASDP, the Government will establish new research centers in the central 
coast and northern highland regions. Of a total of about 2,300 researchers of the agricultural 
research institutes, about 40% have postgraduate degrees. To improve agricultural research in 
public  and  private  sectors,  the  upgrading  of  technical  capabilities  of  researchers  and  the 
provision  of  increased  opportunities  for  advanced  education  for  the  researchers  and  new 
graduates are urgently needed. 
 
6.  The  extension  system  in  Viet  Nam  consists  of  four  levels:  the  central  extension 
institutions  based  in  Hanoi,  the  provincial  extension  network, the  district  network,  and  the 
grassroots or commune-level network. In addition, there are private service providers, including 
farmer associations, NGOs, and private volunteers. At the central level, the Department of 
Agriculture and Forestry Extension (DAFE) under MARD has overall responsibility for planning, 
budgeting,  and  monitoring  of  agricultural  extension  services  for  the  whole  country.  The 
Government recognizes the need for strengthening the local extension networks, including 
private service providers, and the linkage between farmers and agro-based enterprises, and 
plans  to  add  about  5,000  extension  personnel  by  2005,  including  substantial  increases  in 
women and staff of indigenous people. 
 
7.  Although the Government receives assistance in agriculture from major external funding 
agencies, including ADB, the Australian Agency for International Development, the Food and 
Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, the German Agency for Technical Cooperation, 
and the World Bank, the agricultural research and extension system in Viet Nam generally lacks 
sufficient funds to carry out their assigned tasks. For instance, public spending on agricultural 
research constitutes only 0.15% of total Government expenditures in Viet Nam as compared 
with the average of about 0.51% in other countries in Asia. Physical facilities and equipment for 
agriculture S&T have often deteriorated due to lack of funding and maintenance, and must be 
upgraded and modernized to meet future challenges. Scientific cooperation and coordination 
among institutions also need to be promoted to ensure optimal use of scarce financial and 
human resources, and to avoid duplication of efforts. Increased investment expenditures will be 
required for these purposes. 
 
8.  In its policy on agriculture S&T, the Government aims to (i) increase investments for the 
application of new agricultural technologies, (ii) promote the role of the private sector in the 
production of improved planting materials and in research and extension, and (iii) support 
universities in their activities for agricultural research and education. The Government also 
intends to develop some of the lead universities or training centers as international centers for 
specialized extension training and for the training of trainers, particularly for other countries of 
the Greater Mekong Subregion.3 
 
                                                
3  The Greater Mekong Subregion includes Cambodia, Yunnan Province of the People's Republic of China, Lao 
People's Democratic Republic, Myanmar, Thailand, and Viet Nam.

3 
9.  To achieve these policy objectives, collaboration among a wide range of stakeholders, 
including the Government, the private sector, and external funding agencies, will be required. In 
1997, MARD established the International Support Group (ISG) with external funding agencies 
in Viet Nam to effectively coordinate and utilize external resources in the agriculture sector. The 
ISG works on a small trust fund contributed by a few donors, and facilitates the information flow 
through newsletters, a website and periodic meetings. The ISG is a small but a potentially 
powerful group, representing funding agencies, civil society organizations, and most ministries 
concerned  with  policies  and  programs  relating  to  agriculture  and  rural  development.  The 
proposed  TA  will  help  strengthen  the  ISG,  and  contribute  to  coordinated  efforts  for  other 
thematic partnerships in the agriculture sector. 
 
10.  In March 2003, ADB assisted the Government in formulating a sector road map for 
agriculture S&T in Viet Nam based on dialogue with key policy makers and stakeholders in the 
sector.4 In line with the long-term development strategy of the Government, this road map called 
for (i) detailed analysis and inventory assessments focused on the agriculture S&T systems in 
Viet Nam; (ii) increased emphasis on client-oriented research and extension; (iii) partnerships 
with  the  private  sector,  NGOs,  and  international  agricultural  research  centers  and  service 
providers; and (iv) provision of comprehensive and quality services with increased focus on 
disadvantaged farm households. The road map also stressed the need for a wider consensus 
on the long-term objectives and strategy, and for investment in the upgrading of physical and 
human resources for agriculture S&T. The TA has been formulated in line with the road map 
and  will  contribute  to  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  for  Viet  Nam,5  which  aims  at 
supporting the country's sustainable economic growth by raising agricultural productivity and 
promoting private agro-enterprises. The TA is essential in preparing specific components of 
ADB's support for agriculture S&T in Viet Nam, and will involve key stakeholders to ensure 
synergy with other projects of ADB and other external funding agencies through its support for 
the ISG. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The  TA  will  help  the  Government  prepare  a  detailed  proposal  for  strengthening 
agriculture S&T in Viet Nam, thereby contributing to the country's sustainable economic growth 
and reduction in rural poverty. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  To achieve its objectives, the TA will (i) conduct an analytical review of the systems, 
networks,  institutions,  budget,  and  expenditures  related  to  agriculture  S&T  in  Viet  Nam, 
including agricultural research, extension, education, training, and market information systems; 
(ii) identify potential for and critical constraints on the country's agriculture S&T development; 
(iii) establish detailed inventories of physical and human resources for agricultural research, 
extension, and education; (iv) examine alternative means and policy options to promote private 
sector  participation  in  agriculture  S&T,  including  intellectual  property  rights,  taxation,  and 
biotechnology; (v) assess the effectiveness of mass media, and information and communication 
technologies in agriculture S&T; (vi) evaluate past and ongoing external assistance in the 
agriculture  sector  and  identify  lessons  learned;  (vii)  prepare  detailed  investment  proposals

suitable for possible ADB financing; (viii) assist the Government in formulating the Government's 
preliminary  and full feasibility  studies; (ix)  carry  out  institutional,  environmental,  and  social 
assessments for the investment proposals and identify measures to prevent or mitigate possible 
risks associated with the proposals; and (x) assess financial and economic costs and benefits. 
The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 1. 
 
13.  The  TA  needs  to  cover  the  relevant  agricultural  research  institutes,  organizations 
involved in agricultural extension and market information systems, and universities and colleges 
to formulate a comprehensive picture of agriculture S&T in Viet Nam. As these institutes and 
organizations are being restructured under the ongoing ASDP (footnote 2), the progress of 
ASDP  implementation  needs  to  be  fully  taken  into  account  in  an  analytical  review  of  the 
agriculture S&T systems under the TA. Close interactions need to be maintained throughout the 
TA with the relevant government agencies (including MARD, MOET, MOI, MOFI and MOST), 
the private sector, and external funding agencies, and through the ISG. The TA also needs to 
reflect the situation and trends of domestic and international markets for agricultural inputs and 
outputs in determining priorities in agriculture S&T that are responsive to national development 
goals. 
 
14.  The proposed ensuing loan project will be formulated based on the investment needs 
and timetable to be agreed with the Government, and will complement the ongoing and planned 
activities of other external funding agencies and NGOs. The project was initially identified in 
conjunction with the ongoing ASDP, and will be formulated under the TA as the policy and 
institutional reform measures are implemented under the ASDP. The summary initial poverty 
and social analysis was based on the data and information compiled during the processing of 
ASDP  (Appendix  2).  The  ensuing  project  will  aim  at  strengthening  the  institutions  and 
organizations  involved  in  agriculture  S&T  through  investment  in  training  of  their  staff, 
rehabilitation and modernization of facilities and equipment, and improvement of information 
networks.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.125 million equivalent, comprising $655,000 in 
foreign exchange and $470,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will provide $900,000 
equivalent to finance the entire foreign exchange costs and part of the local currency costs, 
amounting to $245,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the Japan 
Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The balance of the local currency costs, 
amounting  to  $225,000  equivalent,  will  be  met  by  the  Government  to  cover  office 
accommodations,  counterpart  staff  support,  facilities  for  seminars  and  meetings,  other 
administrative expenses, and part of local transport costs. A government representative will be 
invited as an observer for contract negotiations. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3. 
The Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing 
any ensuing loan project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be MARD, which is the principal ministry for the 
agriculture sector in Viet Nam, and supervises the majority of agricultural research institutes and 
organizations involved in agricultural extension and market information systems. MARD is also 
the executing agency for the ASDP and the related advisory TA to support the implementation 
of the policy reforms under the ASDP. A project coordination group will be established to 
oversee TA implementation. The group will be headed by the vice minister of MARD for S&T,

5 
and will comprise representatives from MARD, MOST, MOET, MOI, MOFI, the Ministry of 
Planning and Investment, the Ministry of Finance, and the State Bank of Viet Nam. The project 
coordination  group  will  be  responsible  for  (i)  overall  policy  direction  and  guidance,  (ii) 
coordination within the Government, (iii) resolution of outstanding TA implementation issues, 
and (iv) provision of comments on major consultant outputs. In addition, a project preparation 
unit,  headed  by  a  director-level  official,  will  be  established  in  MARD  to  ensure  smooth 
implementation of the TA. This unit will consist of representatives from various departments of 
MARD, including the Agriculture Projects Management Board; the Department for Science, 
Technology  and  Product  Quality;  DAFE;  the  Organization  and  Personnel  Department;  the 
International  Cooperation  Department;  the  Information  Center  for  Agriculture  and  Rural 
Development; other relevant agencies of the Government; and the TA consultant team. The 
project preparation unit will meet at least once a month and will report to the project coordination 
group and ADB on implementation progress. 
 
17.  The TA will apply a multistakeholder participatory diagnosis and design approach for 
project preparation, and will be implemented over 9 months commencing in January 2004 with 
completion expected in October 2004. A total of 86 person-months of consulting services will be 
required under the TA, comprising 33 person-months of international and 53 person-months of 
domestic  consultancy  in  agriculture  sector  management,  research  management,  extension 
management, agricultural education, extension training, agricultural market information, financial 
and economic analyses, social development, environment, and institutional development. The 
international agriculture sector management specialist will lead the TA consultant team. An 
international consulting firm will provide all the international and domestic consulting services 
required for the TA. The consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance with ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging 
domestic  consultants.  The  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  will  be  used  for  the 
selection, and the technical proposals invited from the shortlisted consulting firms will be in 
ADB’s  simplified  formats.  The  consultant  will  purchase  the  necessary  office  equipment  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Equipment procured under the TA will be 
handed over to the Government at TA completion. 
 
18.  Stakeholder  workshops  will  be  organized  at  least  three  occasions—the  first  at  the 
inception, and the next two to discuss the draft interim report and the draft final report prepared 
under the TA. The consultant will prepare (i) an inception report including a detailed work 
program, to be submitted within 1 month of the start of the TA and to be discussed at the initial 
tripartite review meeting; (ii) an interim report to present preliminary findings based on the TA's 
interim results, to be submitted by the end of the fourth month of the TA and to be discussed at 
the interim tripartite review meeting; (iii) a draft final report about 2 months before the final report 
and to be discussed at national- and provincial-level workshops and the final tripartite review 
meeting; and (iv) a final report upon completion of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for preparing the Agriculture Science and Technology Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

2.  The specific assignments of the individual consultants are as follows. 
 
3.  Agriculture Sector Management Specialists. The consultants will 
(i)  conduct an analytical review of the overall agriculture sector in Viet Nam with a 
specific  focus  on  the  situation  of  agriculture  science  and  technology  (S&T), 
including  agricultural  research,  extension,  education,  and  market  information 
systems through literature review; consultation meetings with key stakeholders; 
visits to major organizations and institutes; and by building upon analytical works 
previously carried out for the preparation of the Agriculture Sector Development 
Program (ASDP; Loans 1972 and 1973) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
and the sector road map for agriculture S&T in Viet Nam; 
(ii)  examine and list the major past, ongoing, and planned projects in the agriculture 
sector  financed  by  ADB  and  other  external  funding  agencies;  assess 
international  experience  in  agriculture  S&T  systems;  and  identify  important 
lessons learned to be considered in formulating the ensuing loan project for 
agriculture S&T; 
(iii)  assess the relevant development strategies and plans of the Government, ADB, 
and other external funding agencies; and ensure complementarity and synergy of 
the ensuing project with other ongoing and planned projects and programs in Viet 
Nam, including the ASDP; 
(iv)  undertake a cause-and-effect analysis for agriculture S&T; prepare a problem 
tree and a logical framework for the ensuing project; and assess possible risks 
involved in the ensuing loan project; 
(v)  identify the constraints to the private sector's increased participation in agriculture 
S&T, and propose measures to remove such constraints and promote the private 
sector, including intellectual property rights and taxation;

(vi)  examine, in collaboration with the social development specialists, specific means 
to mainstream gender and indigenous peoples issues in agriculture S&T; and 
incorporate them into the design of the ensuing project; 
(vii)  provide  a  detailed  proposal  for  a  Mekong  regional  platform  for  agricultural 
research and extension in collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural 
Development (MARD) and other key institutions; 
(viii)  assess, in collaboration with other TA consultants, the needs for upgrading and 
developing human resources, physical facilities, and equipment in agriculture 
S&T; and establish detailed inventories for determining investment priorities; 
(ix)  determine specific objectives, scope, and implementation arrangements for the 
ensuing project, including disbursement, procurement, and consulting services; 
and lead the consultant team in formulating the detailed investment proposals to 
be financed under the ensuing project; 
(x)  ensure that all important aspects of the ensuing project are fully assessed in 
terms of its technical, environmental, social, financial, and economic viability; and 
(xi)  lead  the  consultant  team  to  assist  the  Government  in  formulating  the 
Government's preliminary and full feasibility studies in conformity with the TA 
outputs and findings. 
 
4.  Agricultural Research Management Specialists. The consultants will 
(i)  assess  the  agricultural  research  system;  and  identify  potential,  constraints, 
opportunities, and incentives to promote and improve the system in view of the 
national development goals, the trends of domestic and international markets for 
agricultural inputs and outputs, and their autonomous governance system; 
(ii)  assess  the  efficiency  of  agricultural  research  activities  in  terms  of  practical 
application  of  research  results,  collaboration  among  institutions  involved  in 
research, and costs and benefits of research activities and service delivery; 
(iii)  examine the existing methods of research fund allocation; identify means to 
increase  transparency  and  accountability,  and  means  (through  user  fees, 
proprietary licenses, etc.) to improve cost recovery in research and extension 
activities and services; and the beneficiaries’ ability to afford the proposed cost 
recovery scheme and possible measures to mitigate adverse impact on the rural 
poor; 
(iv)  examine the existing network with foreign and international agricultural research 
institutions, and recommend specific means to improve and expand this network; 
(v)  examine the Government's policies and strategies on the use of biotechnology to 
contribute to food  security  and  poverty  reduction  in  Viet  Nam,  and  propose 
regulatory functions of the Government, necessary for an improved approach to 
biotechnology; 
(vi)  conduct detailed assessments of the human resources of research institutes, 
universities, colleges and technical schools for agricultural research; establish an 
inventory  of  the  human  resource  capacity;  and  prepare  a  training  plan  for 
advanced degree and nondegree skills development programs; 
(vii)  estimate  the  investment  requirements  for  strengthening  agricultural  research 
based on the training plan; 
(viii)  assess the research stations, laboratories, greenhouses and research farms; 
establish detailed inventories of research facilities and equipment; and estimate 
the investment required for upgrading and developing them to meet the country's 
priority research needs, particularly in view of the need for improving research 
facilities in remote and upland areas; and

(ix)  help reflect the findings and assessments in the Government's preliminary and 
full feasibility studies. 
 
5.  Agricultural Extension Management Specialists. The specialists will 
(i)  assess the current status of agricultural extension services provided by MARD, 
provincial  governments,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  private 
enterprises and other agents through literature review and visits to selected 
areas; compile information on the present situation of public and private service 
deliveries;  and  recommend  specific  means  to  strengthen  the  country's 
agricultural  extension  system,  promote  participatory  and  group-based 
approaches, and facilitate the private sector's participation; 
(ii)  review the mechanism of fund allocation for agricultural extension by the central 
and provincial governments; and recommend how this fund allocation can be 
improved to ensure that it addresses the needs of the remote and upland areas  
and that there is balance in funding for training and other extension activities; 
(iii)  assess the effectiveness of mass media and information and communication 
technologies in agricultural extension to increase the speed and coverage of 
extension  service  delivery;  and  consider  the  means  for  the  Department  of 
Agriculture and Forestry Extension (DAFE) and other extension institutions to 
make better use of the agricultural market information and analysis system of 
MARD's Information Center for Agriculture and Rural Development (ICARD); 
(iv)  examine  international  experience  in  agricultural  extension  and  training,  and 
assess how public incentives can be effectively used to promote private sector 
participation in these activities; 
(v)  determine  the  needs  and  scope  for  improving  human  resources,  physical 
facilities, and equipment for agricultural extension services; establish detailed 
inventories of the existing human resource capacity, facilities, and equipment; 
and estimate the resource requirements to upgrade and develop such resources; 
(vi)  organize necessary training programs related to the TA and the ensuing project, 
including  in-country  training  for  project  management,  to  enhance  the 
effectiveness and efficiency of the ensuing project; and 
(vii)  identify and recommend means to improve MARD's administrative and regulatory 
responsibilities, and increase the number of agricultural extension staff in remote 
and mountainous areas. 
 
6.  Agricultural Education Specialists. The specialists will 
(i)  assess the curricula of agricultural universities, colleges, and technical schools; 
conduct participatory consultations with selected local communities to assess 
experience of community education programs; and recommend specific means 
to  make  the  agricultural  education  system  more  responsive  to  national 
development  goals  and  priorities,  and  to  improve  the  quality  and  technical 
capabilities of graduates; 
(ii)  identify the needs and scope for improving human resources, physical facilities, 
and equipment for agricultural education; and establish inventories and estimate 
the investment requirements to upgrade and develop such resources; and 
(iii)  examine, in collaboration with the agricultural extension training specialists, the 
feasibility of the Government's proposal to develop some of the lead universities 
or training centers as international centers for specialized extension training and 
for the training of trainers, particularly for other countries of the Greater Mekong 
Subregion; and, if feasible, formulate a specific plan regarding its appropriate 
location, structure, mandate, functional modalities, and financial requirements.

7.  Agricultural Extension Training Specialists. The specialists will 
(i)  examine the potential role of subject matter specialists in providing technical 
assistance to and training of extension staff at the local levels; 
(ii)  assess the effectiveness of mass media and information and communication 
technologies in strengthening the training programs for extension staff at the 
central and local levels; 
(iii)  examine  the  quality  of  extension  training  facilities  of  DAFE,  the  provincial 
departments  of  agriculture  and  rural  development,  universities  and  colleges, 
NGOs,  and  private  sector  organizations;  and  recommend  specific  means  to 
improve the quality of training manuals, trainers, and programs to meet the 
training needs of farmers and extension staff; and 
(iv)  estimate  resource  requirements  for  the  improved  system  and  network  of 
extension training in the country. 
 
8.  Agricultural Market Information Specialists. The consultants will 
(i)  examine the pilot agricultural market information system of ICARD and ICARD's 
technical and institutional capacity; 
(ii)  assess MARD's plan to expand ICARD's pilot system to increase the coverage in 
terms of subjects, beneficiaries, and locations; and 
(iii)  determine the feasibility of the expanded system to increase area and subject 
coverage;  recommend,  if  feasible,  appropriate  scope  and  implementation 
arrangements; and estimate resource requirements for the expanded system. 
 
9.  Financial and Economic Analyses Specialists. The consultants will 
(i)  prepare cost estimates for the ensuing project with a breakdown of costs into 
foreign  exchange  and  local  currency  cost  categories,  using  the  COSTAB 
software;  and  formulate  an  appropriate  financing  plan,  including  realistic 
contributions from the Government and project beneficiaries; 
(ii)  estimate  all  operating  costs,  and  provide  annual  disbursements  of  funds  in 
accordance with the proposed implementation schedule; and 
(iii)  provide  detailed  financial  and  economic  analyses  of  the  ensuing  project  in 
accordance with the standard practices and relevant guidelines of ADB. 
 
10.  Social Development Specialists. The consultants will 
(i)  carry out social and poverty assessments for the ensuing project in accordance 
with  ADB's  Handbook  on  Poverty  and  Social  Analysis,  Handbook  for 
Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Projects, Gender Checklists in Agriculture, 
and  other  relevant  social  policies  and  guidelines  of  ADB,  with  a  particular 
emphasis on the aspects of involuntary resettlement and affordability of the poor; 
(ii)  identify the ethnic minority and indigenous peoples that may be affected by the 
ensuing project; measure the degree and nature of the project’s impact on these 
people; and prepare an indigenous people's development plan for the ensuing 
project, if required;

SUMMARY INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
 
Sector identified as a national priority in country  Sector identified as a national priority in country poverty  
poverty analysis?   Yes.  partnership agreement (PPA)?   Yes. 
 
Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
 
The agriculture sector accounts for about 22% of the national gross domestic product (GDP), 60% of the total labor 
force, and 30% of the country's exports. The PPA of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) with the Government 
identifies the following strategies to reduce poverty: sustainable economic growth by reforming agricultural research 
and  extension,  increased  private  investment in  agriculture  processing, and  agricultural  market support.  Major 
opportunities exist for increasing agriculture productivity and growth, and ensuring food security and job opportunities, 
thereby contributing to reduction in rural poverty. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis        Proposed Classification: Economic growth 
 
 
Rural poverty is widespread in Viet Nam, particularly in remote and highland areas. The country's poverty incidence is 
estimated at about 37% in 2000, and 85% of the poor live in rural areas. Low agriculture productivity and weak 
competitiveness in markets are major explanatory factors for rural poverty in Viet Nam. Poor people in rural Viet Nam 
have limited access to land and other productive resources, and are vulnerable to natural disasters such as flood and 
drought. A detailed poverty analysis is not relevant for the technical assistance (TA) as no specific targeting of the 
poor in certain areas or locations will be required under the ensuing project. However, the TA will carry out social and 
poverty assessments for the project in accordance with ADB's standard practices and guidelines to assess the 
potential impact of the project on gender, indigenous peoples, and rural poverty, and to improve the project design. 
The TA will build on the country poverty analysis and sector work prepared during the formulation of ADB's 
Agriculture Sector Development Program (loans 1972 and 1973) and other relevant studies and reports on the 
country's poverty situation. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Stakeholder analysis:  
 
Under the TA, a series of stakeholder consultation meetings will be required at regional centers (tentatively at eight 
locations in the northern, central, and southern regions) with farmer representatives, local government agencies, 
nongovernment organizations, and the private sector. The International Support Group (ISG), which was established 
by the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development to ensure effective coordination and consultation between the 
Government and external funding agencies, will be effectively used to facilitate dialogue with other external funding 
agencies. National-level workshops will be organized at major milestones of the TA. 
 
Participation strategy required: 
 
The detailed strategy for the participation of key stakeholders in the TA activities will be formulated at TA inception as 
part of the work program for the TA.
